doc.name: TxCoordination
doc.description: TXCoordination class is responsible for initiating a session. After a packet arrives from the network layer, TXCoordination will generate RTS if the packet is long enough. It will send RTS to the destination and wait for CTS. If CTS is received within a specified interval, data will be sent after SIFS seconds. If ACK is received within a given time after the data is sent, the session is complete. TXCoordination will go to backoff before handling the next packet in the queue.If the network packet is not long enough, RTS/CTS will not be used to reduce overhead. In either case, Carrier sense is only done for the first message in the sequence, which is RTS, retransmitted data or data if RTS is not used. TXCoordination gets the channel status by sending a backoff signal with count 0 to the Backoff process in the Transmission block.If the channel turns to be busy, TXCoordination will send another backoff signal with count -1 to start the real backoff. If CTS or ACK is not received in time, the corresponding RTS or data will neeed to be retransmitted. TXCoordination will increase the corresponding retry counters. The backoff window size is also exponentially increased Retransmission will not start until another backoff is completed to avoid congestion.
